subject: Re: [junit] debuggers
msgSnippet: I completed my first professional Ruby project a week ago. It was nothing big: three weeks of Saturdays -- but it was my first professional project with a
messageBody:
I completed my first professional Ruby project a week ago. It was nothing big: three weeks of Saturdays -- but it was my first professional project with a dynamically-typed language with no type checker. This caused me some problems, just because I'm not used to it. I usually say, "The compiler just stops me from making mistakes that I don't make anyway." I suppose that's not quite right for me.

Anyhow, that's just a lead-in to my comment. In many cases, I would have either an unexpected 'nil' value, or an object that doesn't understand an expected message. My first instinct is to get in there with "p this" and "p that"... then I thought of this: if I have a 'nil' object over here, then there must be a bug over there... and when I started writing tests checking that results are non-nil over there, I no longer needed to trace my code.

I'm still learning.

So said steven.hale@... on 3/13/2003 --------------------

My debugging habits are usually something like this:

1. Read the error message (if there is one)
2. Think
3. Read the log
4. Think
5. Write a unit test
6. Launch the debugger

Since adopting junit (2 -3 years ago) I can honestly say I've not yet been
forced down to level 6! I try to encourage programmers in my team not to
start at 6 first.

Judging by the varied responses there's clearly a whole range of other
successful strategies - maybe it's related to the type of application being
programmed.

Steven
